doc.field: <description type="note">Only "Rawlinson NT strophic passages" included; non-English verse omitted.</description>

I. Lucas.Square brackets denote editorial insertions or emendations. 1 Luke in his lesson leres to me, How Gabryel was graythed in gracyus degre; Fro Ã¾e heuen upon hight hasted was he To Mary, Ã¾at mayden, Ã¾at fair was & fre, WiÃ¾ ane O & ane I, vnto a cete Ã¾at was named Nazareth in land of Galile. 2 He marked to Ã¾at mayden myghtful of mede Ã¾at mowthed was Mary wiÃ¾outen mysdede, Ã¾at wowed was wiÃ¾ Joseph worthly in wede, And he of Dauid hows, if ye tak hede. WiÃ¾ ane O & and ane I, yhederly he yhede Vnto Ã¾at berd bowsom his bodword to bede. 3 Comly he knelt opon his o kne And putt furth his fynger full fair to Ã¾at fre. He said: hail, full of grace, god es wiÃ¾ Ã¾e, Of all berdes Ã¾at bene blyssed mot Ã¾ou be. WiÃ¾ ane O & ane I, asschamed was scho And thoght: what euer menes Ã¾is message to me? 4 Styll in a stody scho stode in hir stall, Ã¾an said Ã¾e aungell: Ã¾ou worthly in wall, Be noght ferd in Ã¾is fare, if ferlyes befall, Of god grace has Ã¾ou geten gretest of all; WiÃ¾ ane O & ane I, sothly Ã¾ou sall Consayue a child ioyfull & Jesus him call. 5 He sall be gracyus & gud & of gret myght, And son of Ã¾e heghest here sall he hyght; In Ã¾e sege of Dauid his sete sall be dyght, And in Ã¾e hows of Jacob won sall Ã¾at wight. WiÃ¾ ane O & ane I, his ryche regne be ryght Sall neuer lessen ne leue, bot last ay in lyght. 6 Mary answerd & asked: how so suld bigyn? I knew neuer in Ã¾is kyth kynde of mankyn. Ã¾an Ã¾e aungell hir warned warely wiÃ¾ wyn: Ã¾e haly gast of Ã¾i god sall lyght Ã¾e wiÃ¾in, WiÃ¾ ane O & ane I, his might more & myn Vmbeschadow Ã¾e sall wiÃ¾outen ony syn. 7 Lo how Elizabeth Ã¾i cosyn [?boght], [Now] in hir eld sall [consaiue] a son [?] soght. Ã¾e sext moneth es Ã¾is, think [Ã¾ou] in thoght, Scho es named baran, na barn furth [scho] broght. WiÃ¾ ane O & ane I, to neuen es Ã¾are noght Vnmyghtfull to god Ã¾at Ã¾is world wroght. 8 Ã¾an Mary full warly hir wordes gan wale: Lo here, godes seruand, [so sen] him Ã¾ou sale; Als Ã¾ou has said in Ã¾is tyme to me Ã¾is tale, Be it done, as Ã¾ou demes, be doun & bi dale. WiÃ¾ ane O & ane I, Ã¾us [hers yhe] all hale, How scho harbard wiÃ¾ Ã¾at barn Ã¾at broght vs of bale. II. Matheus. 1 Mathew his manhede [mowthed to me]. He said: Jesus was born in Bethleem Jude, When sir Herod was kyng in Ã¾at contre, And euen out of Ã¾e est come kynges thre, WiÃ¾ ane O & ane I, wiÃ¾ gyftes full fre, So Ã¾at semely Ã¾ai soght to Ã¾at cete. 2 Ã¾an carpes Ã¾e kynges to haue knawyng: Whare es he Ã¾at es born to be Jewes kyng? We saw his stern in Ã¾e est spedily vpspryng, And we er boune to Ã¾at barne our [bewtese] to bring. WiÃ¾ ane O & ane I, Ã¾ai spyrd of Ã¾at yhing, Bot kyng Herod had tene of Ã¾air tything. 3 He sent efter princes & [prestes] of Ã¾e law And other many ma[isters restand] on raw. He enquerd, when Ã¾ai [come, if Ã¾ai] couth knaw, Whare swilk a barne suld be born, [offryng to schaw]. WiÃ¾ ane O & ane I, Ã¾ai said in Ã¾air saw: In bethleem to be born [euen?] 4 On Ã¾is wise [Ã¾ir] prophetes haue speken in Ã¾air spell: Ã¾ou Bethleem of Jude, Ã¾[us mene Ã¾ai Ã¾e mell?], Ã¾e lest land ertow noght, trewly [to tell], Out of Ã¾e bese [a d]uke dight here for [to dwell]. WiÃ¾ ane O & ane I, thurgh [?] Sall he defend Ã¾e folk of all Israell. 5 Sir Herod Ã¾an carpes to Ã¾e kynges thre: Wendes sauely & sekes, Ã¾e soth till yhe se; When yhe haue fonden Ã¾at barn Ã¾at [fares so] fre And do[n]e him worschep wiÃ¾ will, [wend] & warn me. WiÃ¾ ane O & ane I, blyth will I be For to worschip Ã¾at wight wiÃ¾ my m[aine]. 6 When Ã¾ir kynges had hard, how Ã¾at he had hyght, Ful forth on Ã¾air way rayked Ã¾ai ryght; Of Ã¾e stern Ã¾at Ã¾ai soght sone had Ã¾ai syght [?] abouen Bethleem wiÃ¾ bemes full bright. WiÃ¾ ane O & ane I, Ã¾air leder was hyght, Ã¾at myld wiÃ¾ his moder so musterd his might. 7 Into Ã¾e hows er Ã¾ai comen wiÃ¾outen any call, Ã¾e barn fand Ã¾ai bonden in a best stall, WiÃ¾ Mary his moder full wynly in wall, And to knaw him for kyng on knes gan Ã¾ai fall. WiÃ¾ ane O & ane I, say yhow I sall: Gold, Myrr & encens offerd Ã¾ai all. 8 When Ã¾ir dedes war done duly Ã¾at day, Ã¾e kynges layd Ã¾am to slepe softly, I say. And Ã¾us or Ã¾ai wakend, warned war Ã¾ai: Metes wiÃ¾ sir Herod no more, if yhe may! WiÃ¾ ane O & ane I, be ane other way Went ilk lord to his land, als Ã¾e strete lay. III. Markus. 1 Marke of his myghtes myldely gan neuen Restand on a raw disciples elleuen; To Ã¾am appered Jesus, god son of heuen, Ã¾air mysbileue to amend wiÃ¾ a myld steuen. WiÃ¾ ane O and ane I, Ã¾ai wald noght trow euen To Ã¾am Ã¾at tald, how he rayse mo sythes Ã¾an seuen. 2 He said: ouer al Ã¾e world I will Ã¾at yhe wende, Ã¾e gospell sall yhe preche Ã¾at neuer sall haue ende To euerilka creature, to fa & to frende: Who trowes & es baptist, no syn sall him schend; WiÃ¾ ane O and ane I, he Ã¾at will lende Vnbaptist, he bese feffed wiÃ¾ Ã¾e fende. 3 All Ã¾at made er my men, my signe sall Ã¾ai were, In my name gett Ã¾ai force fendes to fere, WiÃ¾ new tonges sall Ã¾ai speke & my law lere, And nedders & wormes oway sall Ã¾ai were. WiÃ¾ ane O and ane I, now take Ã¾e no care, And euell venym to drynk sall do Ã¾am no dere. 4 An seke men sall Ã¾ai sett sadly Ã¾air hende And thurgh myght of my merk sone sall Ã¾ai mend. When Crist to Ã¾at company Ã¾us kyndely had kend, Vnto heuen in Ã¾air syght sone he [des]cend; WiÃ¾ ane O and ane I, Ã¾are lykes him to lend, On his fader ryght hand [?] wiÃ¾outen end. 5 Ã¾e apostels playnly passed Ã¾are pase Prechand Ã¾e pople in euerilka place, Crist was Ã¾air comforth in ilka kene case And wele confermed Ã¾air wordes, als his wil wase. WiÃ¾ ane O and ane I, Ã¾us toke Ã¾ai Ã¾air trace Folewand Ã¾e ferlyes Ã¾at felles our fase. IV. Joh'n. 1 Joh'n of his heghnes tyll our hereyng Says Ã¾at Ã¾e son was in Ã¾e bigynyng, And Ã¾e son was Ã¾e god Ã¾at bote may vs bryng, And on Ã¾is wise was it Ã¾an [?our] heuen king. WiÃ¾ ane O and ane I, both old & yhing Es bi him & wiÃ¾ him, wiÃ¾outen him no thing. 2 Thing Ã¾at in him was, made lyf was it ryght, And Ã¾at lyfe, sall we leue, es of mens lyght; Ã¾at lyght in Ã¾e myrknes schynes full bryght, And myrknes may noght mer him of myght. WiÃ¾ ane O and ane I, to wiss ilka wight, Fra god was a man sent & Joh'n Ã¾an he hight. 3 And he come to Ã¾is world for to witnes Lyght Ã¾at suld comforth Ã¾e corne & Ã¾e gress; He ne was noght Ã¾e lyght graythly to gess, Bot who was lyght lely, proued he express. WiÃ¾ ane O and ane I, verray lyght es Ã¾at lyghtens men on Ã¾is mold more & less. 4 In Ã¾is word witerly wondin he wase, And als all Ã¾is mydlerth myldely he mase, Ã¾e world had no knawyng of him in Ã¾at case; Into his awen, when he come, none herberd him hase. WiÃ¾ ane O & ane I, who takes his trace, To be made god sons gaf he Ã¾am grace, 5 To Ã¾am Ã¾at his name leues loud & styll And nowther born er of blode ne of flessch will, Bot Ã¾at geten er of god wiÃ¾outen any ill; And so Ã¾e son es made flessch folk to fulfill. WiÃ¾ ane O & ane I, we seke Ã¾is skyll, His ioy fyld full of grace graythed vs tyll. Amen.

I. Fer. IV Quat. temp. secundum Lucam. Missus est angelus Gabriel a deo etc. Fra god was sent ane angel brightâ Gabriel for soth he hightâ To Nazareth a riche cite, Was in Ã¾e land of Galile, In message til a clene virgin Ã¾at comen was of Dauid kin. Spowsed was Ã¾at mayden bright Vnto a man Ã¾at Joseph hight; Ã¾e maiden name was cald Mary, Omang all wemen most worthy. Ã¾e angel come to hir fra heuyn And said to hir with milde steuyn: Hail be Ã¾ou Mari, maiden fre, Ful of grace, god es with Ã¾e! Ã¾ou ert blisced in wemen all, All folk to Ã¾e sal socoure call, And fruit Ã¾at of Ã¾i wambe sal wende Sal be blisced withowten ende. When Mari herd, how Ã¾at he saide, Within hir hert scho wex afraide. Sho had meruaile, what thing it ment Ã¾at Ã¾e angel so to hir was sent, And in hir hert scho had grete thoght, Thurgh his wordes what suld be wroght. Ã¾an said Ã¾e angel milde of mode To Ã¾e mayden Ã¾at so stodiand stode: Mari, he said, ne drede Ã¾e noght, Of Ã¾is bodworde I haue Ã¾e broght. Grace hastow funden in al thing Onence my lorde of heuyn king. Ã¾ou sal consaiue and bere a childe, And flessheli saltou noght be filde; A sun Ã¾ou sal consaiue and bere, Ã¾i maidenhed it sal noght dere; Jesus sal Ã¾ou Ã¾i sun call, And sal be sauioure of all; Heghest goddes sun he sal be cald, And mighti god sun men sal him hald. Oure lorde god of graces grete Thurgh mightes sal him gif Ã¾e sete Of his fader, Ã¾e king Dauid, To gouern his regne in pese and grith And regne he sal, moste king to neuyn, Wirshipt of all angels of heuyn; In mekil might ay sal he lend In Jacob house withowten end; Regne he sal in rest and pese, His regne sothli sal neuer sese, Ã¾an saide Mari with milde mode Vnto Ã¾e angel, Ã¾are he stode: How suld be done to me Ã¾is thing, Sen I of man had neuer knawing? When Ã¾e angel Ã¾ir wordes herd, Vnto Ã¾e maiden Ã¾us he answerd: Mari, of me Ã¾ou haue no drede, Ã¾ou sal noght mis Ã¾i maidenhede, Ã¾e haligaste of god of might, Lady, in Ã¾e sal he light; Ã¾e vertu of god moste to fele Sall vmbilap Ã¾e ilkadele. Als minister Ã¾us sent am I Vnto Ã¾e fra god almighty, Ã¾e same Ã¾at of Ã¾e sal be borne Ã¾us has me sent to Ã¾e biforne. etc. [26 lines omitted.] And lo, bihald, mi ladi clere, Elizabeth, Ã¾i cosyn dere, Scho has consaiued now in hir elde And hir bodi now fruit sal ?elde, To bere a child now scho bigins Ã¾at goddes sun so bifore rins. And now Ã¾is es Ã¾e sext moneth Ã¾at Ã¾is woman Elizabeth Was named barayn in ilka place, Now gase scho grete thurgh goddes grace. Now men sese hir with childe gang, Ã¾at barayn bifore was named lang. How so god wil here ordayne, It may no thing be Ã¾aire ogayne; All thinges Ã¾at er bus buwe bi skill Paisibilly vnto goddes will. Mari full meke goddes wil to do, Ã¾us scho said Ã¾e angell vnto; Ecce ancilla domini fiat michi etc. Lo here goddes handmaiden puruaid, To me be done als Ã¾ou has said, Ã¾e will allane of my lorde dere Be done to me on al manere! And when Ã¾e aungel Ã¾us had done, To heuyn ogayne he went ful sone, And blisced Mari Ã¾e maiden chaste Dwelt fulfild of Ã¾e hali gaste. II. In die Epiphanie secundum Matheum Cum natus esset Jesus in Bethleem. When oure lord Jesu so fre Was born in Bedleem of Jude In Herodes daies to vnderstand Ã¾at lord was Ã¾an of al Ã¾at land, Ouer Bedlem stode a stern ful bright, Ouer ilkaland lasted Ã¾e light. Cristes birth it puplist playn Inogh, Ã¾e folk fro fer landes Ã¾eder drogh, And kinges out of sere cuntre Soght Ã¾at solempne sight to se, For to fulfil Ã¾e wordes algate Ã¾at Dauid in his psalmes wrate. etc. Vbi est qui natus est rex Judeorum? vidimus enim stellam eius etc. Whare es he Ã¾at born es ?ing, Ã¾at of al Ã¾e Jewri sal be king? We saw a taken out of Ã¾e est, He sall be lord of man and best, For whi Ã¾at stern witht bemes brigh Proues Ã¾at he es god of might, Ã¾at es Ã¾e cause, whi we Ã¾us cum, For he es born in Ã¾is kingdom; Oure giftes als to him we bring To honore him als for oure king; We sal him gif of oure tresoure Als till oure god and sauioure. Ã¾us Ã¾ai spird in Ã¾at cete, In what stede god sun born sul be, etc. Conuocacio magorum Hastily Ã¾an gert he (= Herod) call Ã¾e bisshoppes, princes and prestes all, And all Ã¾e scribes Ã¾at knew Ã¾e law, And Jewes Ã¾at war wisist of saw, And all Ã¾at prophecies kowth luke, Vnto his counsail he Ã¾am toke And praied Ã¾am ilkone on Ã¾aire wise To seke omang Ã¾aire prophecies And tell him sone for any thing, Out what cuntre Crist suld spring, And Ã¾at Ã¾ai lett noght euyn ne morn, Till Ã¾ai wit whare he sal be born. Ã¾ai went and luked Ã¾e bukes on raw, Till Ã¾ai Ã¾e soth might clerely knaw. Ã¾an tald Ã¾e to Ã¾e king bidene, Als Ã¾ai in prophecies had sene; Ã¾ai said Ã¾at Crist here born suld be, In Bedleem Ã¾e Cete of Jude. Ã¾ai said it suld be so algate Micheas of his birth Ã¾us wrate And said Ã¾at men may vnderstand: Ã¾ou Bedleem of Juda land, Ã¾ou es noght leste loued to be Omang Ã¾e princes of Jude! Out of Ã¾e a duke sall rise To lede my folk in domes rightwise, Als duke in Ã¾is werld sal he dwell To saue my folk of Israell. etc. Tunc Herodes clam uocatis magis diligenter didicit ab eis tempus stelle. When Herod by Ã¾aire wordes wist Ã¾at Ã¾is thing was Ã¾us puplist, His hert rase ful felunsly Ogayns Ã¾e childe with grete enuy, And in his hert ful fast he thoght, How Ã¾is childe might to ded be broght, And preuely how it might be Ã¾at nane sold wit bot his men?e. Thurght hid malice Ã¾us wirk he wald, Ã¾ar fore Ã¾e kinges ful faire he cald, Of Ã¾am he soght and spied ful ?erne Ã¾e tyme and Ã¾e state of Ã¾e sterne, And preuely of Ã¾am he lered, How Ã¾e sterne to Ã¾am appered. And al Ã¾e soth when he it knew, Thurgh karping of Ã¾ir kinges trew, Vnto Bedleem sone he Ã¾am sent And said to Ã¾am Ã¾us, or Ã¾ai went: Wendes, he said, sirs, I ?ow pray And enqueres bisily, if ?e may, Al Ã¾e condicyouns preuely Of Ã¾e childe Ã¾at es so worthi. For maisters vnto me has talde Ã¾at he sall haue grete welth in walde; Ã¾ar fore, when ?e haue fun Ã¾at fre, Cumes heder ogayn and telles me, In what stede Ã¾at ?e him find, Ã¾e childe Ã¾at so sal lese and bind, For vnto him Ã¾an wend will I And honore him, als es worthi; Sen swilk a lord lendes in my land, Vnto him will I bring offerand. Bot falshede euer in his hert he thoght, To sla Ã¾e childe, if Ã¾at he moght. Ã¾us when Ã¾e kinges his wordes herd, Ã¾ai toke Ã¾aire leue and furth Ã¾ai ferd. Ã¾aire signe ful sone rase Ã¾am biforn, Ã¾e sterne with light Ã¾at Ã¾ai had lorn; For fra Ã¾ai vnto Herod thoght, In Ã¾at sesoun Ã¾ai saw it noght, And seÃ¾in it rase ogain ful faire And went byfor Ã¾am in Ã¾e aire. With Ã¾at light Ã¾us war Ã¾ai led, Vntill Ã¾ai come to Ã¾e same stede, Whare childe was, and Ã¾an it stode Obouen Ã¾at stede and no fer ?ode. Ã¾e kinges Ã¾an war ferly faine, For Ã¾aire light was cumen ogaine, And mekill mirth in hert Ã¾ai made, When Ã¾ai saw, whare Ã¾e stern abade. Ã¾e hows entred Ã¾a kinges thre, Whare simpill hostell was to se. Ã¾ai fand Ã¾e childe godsun almighty With his moder milde Mari, And sune Ã¾ir kinges of fer cuntrese Bifor Ã¾is childe kneled on Ã¾air knese, With wirchip and deuocion, Ã¾ai honord him als goddes sun. Ã¾ai opind Ã¾aire tresore in Ã¾at stede, And riche giftes to him Ã¾ai bed, In Ã¾aire offring Ã¾are Ã¾ai did Gold and ensens and mir Ã¾e thrid. etc. [14 lines omitted.] And when Ã¾ai had Ã¾ir dedes done; Ã¾aire waies ogainward went Ã¾ai sone; And als Ã¾ai slepid on Ã¾e first night, To Ã¾am aperd ane angell bright. And warned Ã¾am with wordes hende Ã¾at Ã¾ai suld noght by Herod wende, Bot hamward tak anoÃ¾er strete And with Ã¾at man namore to mete. Ã¾us warned in Ã¾aire dreme Ã¾at Ã¾ai suld wend fro Bedleem, And efter Ã¾ir wordes when Ã¾ai woke, AnoÃ¾er way hamward Ã¾ai toke. So in Ã¾aire kingdoms er Ã¾ai sett, With Herod Ã¾e king namore Ã¾ai mett. III. Incipit hic secunda particula euangelii. Ostensio diuinitatis in Christo. In die natali domini euangelium secundum Johannem. In principio erat uerbum etc. In Ã¾e bigining was Ã¾e sun, Euyn with his fader alway to won. Ã¾e sun was at Ã¾e bigining With Ã¾e fader to wirk althing, And mighty god alway was he Wonand with his fader fre. Ã¾e sun was at Ã¾e bigining, God with Ã¾e fader ane in althing, Thurgh him al thinges in werld er wroght, And withouten him made es noght. Ã¾e fader Ã¾at al may weld and right With Ã¾e sun al ane in might Made al maner of creatures, Man and bestes, fowles and flowres; Al creatures war made of him, And of his making was no tyme, And al Ã¾at war made with his might Was in Ã¾e werld als verray right. Al thinges war life thurght his wisdome Ã¾at war ordand efter to com, Thurght him Ã¾ai war quik albidene, Als Ã¾ai suld efterward be sene. Criste es life fulfild of might And to lifand men uerray light; Als light to Ã¾is werld born he es Ã¾at schines ful bright omang mirknes. Al erthly men mirknes er cald Ã¾at in vnclennes Ã¾am wil had, Als werldly men of werkes ill Ã¾at lifes ay efter Ã¾aire awin will. Omang slike men god sun decend, Bot his might moght Ã¾ai noght comprehend, For men, Ã¾at here in lustes lifes And to werkes of mirknes Ã¾am gifes, In Ã¾am here may Ã¾ai noght haue Goddes sun Ã¾at cumes man saul to saue. Fuit homo missus a deo A man to erth fra god was sent, Bifor god in his waies he went, He had vnto name John Baptist, God sun thurght him to be puplist. Sent he was Ã¾e folk to teche And Cristes cuming plainly to preche, To waste in erth Ã¾e waies of sin, Man saul thurgh grace to blis at wyn. He come bifore forto witnes Ã¾e come of Criste to more and les And to al men with main and might To bere witnes of werray light, So Ã¾at all folk thurgh him warnist Suld trewly trow in Jesu Criste. John was noght Ã¾at light to taste Ã¾at mirknes in Ã¾is werld might waste, Bot he was sent to bere witnes Of light Ã¾at al Ã¾is werld suld dress And Ã¾at lightnes of mirknes makes And lightnes of none oÃ¾er takes. Verray light for suth he es, Ã¾at lightes al men both more and les. Al men he lightes thurght mightes sere Born of mankind omang men here, Noght by engenderure for to taste, Bot anly of Ã¾e haly gaste. Al thinges cumes of Criste god sun, Withowten him es noght bigun, In Ã¾is werld for soth was he Done in mans sight forto se. Al Ã¾is werld thurgh him was wroght And fully fowrmid first of noght, And Ã¾e werld Ã¾an knew him no thing, For Jews had of him no knawing. To his awin proper places he soght; Ã¾ai Ã¾at was his resayued him noght. For fless and blude toke Criste mighty Of Ã¾e Jewes progeniy, Manhede he toke of Ã¾aire linage, Ã¾am to bring out of seruage. He welk and preched omang Ã¾e Jews And schewed omang Ã¾am sere uertuse, And Ã¾ai wald noght ?it in him trow Ne knaw his cumyng for Ã¾aire prow. Quot quot autem receperunt eum, dedit eis potestatem filios dei fieri. Als many als in Ã¾is werld ware, Ã¾at herd his wordes and trowed his lare And resayued him and knew him euyn Als god sun sent fro Ã¾e fader of heuyn, Vnto Ã¾am gaf he playn powste, Goddes suns of heuyn Ã¾at Ã¾ai suld be. Ã¾e suns of god so he Ã¾am mase Noght thurgh Ã¾aire kind, bot thurght his grace; Vnto all Ã¾a Ã¾at in him trowes And baynly to his bidinges bowes. Vnto Ã¾at grace may no man win For Ã¾e corrupcioun of Ã¾aire sin, Thurgh fless ne blude by day ne night, Ne thurgh none erthly mans might, Als men er born here to endure Of fader and moder engenderure. Ã¾ai may noght win it bi slike will Ne by no werldly werkes ill, Bot born Ã¾ai er thurgh cristendom To mighty god gastly at come, Ã¾at birth es of Ã¾e haligaste Thurgh grace of god of mightes maste. In fless and blude made es god sun Omang vs here in werld to won, Of him in manhede sight had we Ã¾at in godhede we might noght se, His ioy we saw ful verrayly Als anly of god sun almighty, We se him plainly in ilk place Fulfild of gudenes and of grace.

[Of Ã¾es frer mynours me thenkes moch wonder] 1 Of Ã¾es frer mynours me thenkes moch wonder, Ã¾at waxen are Ã¾us hauteyn, Ã¾at som tyme weren vnder; Among men of holy chirch Ã¾ai maken mochel blonder;â Nou he Ã¾at sytes vs aboue make ham sone to sonder. With an O and an I Ã¾ai praysen not seynt Poule, Ã¾ai lyen on seyn[t] Fraunceys, by my fader soule. 2 First Ã¾ai gabben on God, Ã¾at alle men may se, When Ã¾ai hangen him on hegh on a grene tre With leues and with blossemes Ã¾at bright are of ble; Ã¾at was neuer Goddes son, by my leute. With an O and an I, men wenen Ã¾at Ã¾ai wede, To carpe so of clergy, Ã¾ai can not Ã¾air crede. 3 Ã¾ai haue done him on a croys fer vp in Ã¾e skye And festned on him wyenges, as he shuld flie. Ã¾is fals feyned byleue shal Ã¾ai soure bye, On Ã¾at louelych lord so forto lye. With an O and an I, one sayd ful stylle: Armachan distroy ham, if it is Goddes wille. 4 Ã¾er comes one out of Ã¾e skye in a grey goun, As it were an hoghyerd hyand to toun; Ã¾ai haue mo goddes Ã¾en we, I say by Mahoun, Alle men vnder ham Ã¾at euer beres croun. With an O and an I, why shuld Ã¾ai not be shent? Ã¾er wantes noght bot a fyre, Ã¾at Ã¾ai nere alle brent. 5 Went I forther on my way in Ã¾at same tyde; Ã¾er I sawe a frere blede in myddes of his syde, BoÃ¾e in hondes and in fete had he woundes wyde, To serue to Ã¾at same frer, Ã¾e pope mot abyde. With an O and an I, I wonder of Ã¾es dedes, To se a pope holde a dishe, whyl Ã¾e frer bledes. 6 A cart was made al of fyre, as it shuld be; A gray frer I sawe Ã¾er inne, Ã¾at best lyked me. Wele I wote, Ã¾ai shal be brent, by my leaute; God graunt me Ã¾at grace, Ã¾at I may it se. With an O and an I, brent be Ã¾ai alle, And alle Ã¾at helpes Ã¾erto faire mot byfalle. 7 Ã¾ai preche alle of pouert, bot Ã¾at loue Ã¾ai noght; For gode mete to Ã¾air mouÃ¾e, Ã¾e toun is Ã¾urghsoght; Wyde are Ã¾air wonnynges and wonderfully wroght; Murdre and horedome ful dere has it boght. With an O and an I, for sixe pens, er Ã¾ai fayle, Sle Ã¾i fadre, and iape Ã¾i modre, and Ã¾ai wyl Ã¾e assoile. [Godys sone Ã¾at was so fre] 1 Godys sone Ã¾at was so fre, into Ã¾is world he cam And let hym naylyn vpon a tre, al for Ã¾e loue of man. His fayre blod Ã¾at was so fre, out of his body it ran, A dwelful sy?te it was to se, his body heng blak and wan.
